description:
OK Boomer levels the playing field so every generation can compete in this brand new twist on classic trivia! Players will attempt to correctly answer generation specific trivia questions on subjects like History, Science, Trends, Sports, and Entertainment.  Play one of  three different game types? Free for All (every player for themselves), Mixed Gen (teams picked at random), or Generational Clash (teams separated by generation). Collect a card from each of the five generation card decks to claim victory and determine the greatest generation once and for all!

-description from publisher

Originally offered as an add-on during the  Ascension Tactics: The Deckbuilding Miniatures Game Kickstarter campaign.

Ascension: 10 Year Anniversary Edition features:

     Remastered cards for improved gameplay
     New art featuring Ascensions most iconic characters
     All new premium 10th anniversary game board


and contains:

     181 cards (compared to 200 in the original)
     Honor tokens
     The board
     A rule book


—description from the Kickstarter campaign

A 12-part episodic space adventure by Jason Greeno.

Gather your crew and gear and launch into a fringe section of space where the law teeters over the edge and a good captain can earn a living. There's no shortage of threats that endanger the goodfolk of deep space, but luckily your torpedo bay is full and lasers are hot.

In The Final Light-Year you'll play solo or cooperative with a friend, as the captain of a so-called starship, in hopes of earning some rewards and a decent rep. Using tactical maneuvering and dice-based action selection, you'll work through the sector's small, medium and large enemies trying to gain rewards and ultimately live to see another day.

The goal is to defeat all three Enemies (Minion, Commander and Overlord). To do so you'll need to manage your ship's resources, crew and your wits to defeat unique and challengint threats. The game evolves across two turn phases, moving and combating at the Battle Phase (ships) and earning rewards at the Resupply Phase (planets), depending on your current location on the Sector Track. The game ends when you defeat the Overlord and win, or when any player's hull is reduced to 0 and you lose. Good luck with your adventures!

Customizable episodes will challenge you with variable enemies and threats while offering powerful new gear and talented crew to help you in your adventures.


Starter Kit released for Board Game of the Month Club in March 2021 includes Alpha sector.

12 monthly episodes released from March 2021 to February 2022 packages.

In the future, scientists on Earth have opened a portal to a land outside of time.  That land outside of time is full of various forces attempting to take control of other times and places.  Scientists from various Earth futures were ready and waiting with gear and information so that Earth could defend itself.  The 88th Company, "The Timewatch", was formed.  They are the ones who step into There to protect us all.

This is a tactical battle that involves the use of the present and the past.  Units have a piece representing their current position, plus a piece representing a previous position.  Both pieces can be moved (altering the present and the past).  Time can jump backwards to the past positions.

The objective of the game is to control spaces on the game board to gain victory points. The winner is
the player with the most victory points after each player has spent 180 action points.

-description from designer

What are little Johnny, Suzy, and Fido supposed to do when the suburban droll has them down? I know, Let's Summon Demons!  Whether you're building sadistic synergies with the "rotten" kids or sharing the love with the "sweet" kids, only the savviest (and luckiest!) player--the best Demon Summoner--will walk away a winner!


     Shuffle up the Demon Deck and the Block Deck, and deal everyone a Starting Candle and a hand of 3 Demons. Your goal is to summon all 3 of those little devils before your opponents beat you to it... 
     At all times, a rotating assortment of five cards will be available for purchase (the low, low price of 3 soul tokens) to all players--this is called THE BLOCK and it has Boys, Girls, and Animals of every style and strategy! Look for cards that combo together! 
     On each players' turn, they'll roll the dice--if any player's cards they've acquired "match" the total rolled then that card activates--often resulting in the acquisition of more soul tokens! More soul tokens means more cards from THE BLOCK, means even more soul tokens--but to what end?
     Well, you can sacr--er--discard 3 of your cards to SUMMON A DEMON! The most powerful cards of all! Once any player has summoned all 3 of their Demons --and has a balance of 10 souls on top of that--they are declared the ultimate Demon Summoner and the game is over! With all of the variety offered between the 20 unique demons and the diverse BLOCK DECK, there is plenty of content to explore and master!


—description from the publisher

The Ultimate Burger is a simple and fast card game. The goal you ask? As mentioned earlier, simple.
You just need to make The Ultimate Burger.

You don´t knowhow? Let me help you. You need four things - bun, meat, cheese and Jalapeño.

The thing is, everyone wants to make the ultimate burger, but there are not enough ingredients. Sure, there are enough buns and cheese for everyone, but there are only two meat slices and only one Jalapeño!

Players are taking turns. Each turn, you can do two actions - draw a card and play card or any combination of the two. Playing a card means playing an action card or placing an Ingredient card in front of you. The player who has one of each ingredient before him at the end of his turn, wins.

The Ingredients are scattered throughout the deck along with the action cards. It is your job to find them, either by drawing them from the deck or stealing them from another player.

A brand new Candy Crush board game for two players. Players place colorful candies on the game board to create
sweet combinations and earn points. By earning points the bar fills up and the first player to have a full point bar is the winner! Outsmart your opponent with creative solutions and score the most points!

—description from the publisher

Cycling Manager is a unique cycling race game based on relative movement (the cyclists are represented based on their relative position from each other). Players will not have to move their cyclists at each step to make it move forward through the race, they will only have to make them move when they want to !

In Cycling Manager, players take the control of a team of 4 cyclists trying to finish the race in the first position. The race will be composed of a succession of 4 different stage profiles (flat, hills, mountain climb and descent).

The cyclists will be placed in groups all along the race. At the beginning, all cyclists are in the same group (the peloton). At each stage step (each step having its own stage profile), cyclists will be able to:

     Not doing anything (they will stay in their current position), this is what will happen most of time for most of the cyclists
     Change their position in their group (they may want to take the lead in their group or go at the back to rest)
     Attack: Move forward from one group to another. The new group they reach depends on how much energy they spend on the attack (attack can be small, medium or high).
     Move back: move to another group backward, it will allow them to get back some energy/


Cyclists will go through the stage step by step (a typical stage is composed of each 12 stage profiles). At each step, cyclists will be able to perform one action. Actions can be attacking (small, medium or big attack) or move back. An attack will cost energy to cyclist, a move back will give back some. Cyclists will manage their own energies through the stage based on the following :

     Stage profile: cyclists can be more or less comfortable in different profiles (flat, hills, mountain climb and descent) and will spend energy accordingly 
     their position in their group: cyclist will spend less energy if they're protected by other cyclists
     their group's speed: if a group is moving fast (trying to catch another group for instance), they will spend more energy.


At the end of the race, the cyclists in the leading group can compete in the final sprint to get the winner!

—description from the designer

CLACK! Family uses gameplay similar to CLACK!, but with cards replacing the magnetic discs for a smaller, more affordable game.

In the game, you must grab or slap all the cards in play that match the dice combination rolled. Cards each show three objects on them, with those objects being red, green, or blue in color and an animal, tree, or vehicle in type. If you roll "0 - red", then you slap all the cards that have zero red objects on them; if you roll "2 - animal", then you slap all the cards with exactly two animals on them. If you're correct, you claim the cards, then refill the display to seven cards.

If no cards on display match the die roll, grab the "NO MATCH" tile in the center of the player area. If you're correct, you collect all seven cards; if not, you must give a previously collected card to each other player at the table.

When all the cards have been claimed, whoever has collected the most cards wins.

With the right roll of the dice in LAMA Dice, you can rid yourself of number cards — but you'll need to quit at the right time before you possibly bomb out and collect a lot of minus points. You can possibly ditch these points later, but you'll need the perfect number roll or triple llama luck.

In more detail, the game lasts a number of rounds, and at the start of each round you lay out the seven "black-backed" cards that show a llama and the numbers 1-6 in a "llama row". You're dealt six cards from the deck — which consists of llama cards and cards numbered 1-6 — and you lay those cards in front of you. On a turn, you roll the three dice or quit the round; if you roll the dice, then:


    If one or more of the dice match the cards in front of you, you can discard one card for each matching die.
    If you roll three llamas, you can discard one point token that you've collected.
    If none of the dice match cards in your row, then you must take one of the llama row cards that does match and add it to your display.
    If none of the dice match either cards in your row or cards in the llama row, then you must take all remaining cards in the llama row, ending the round.


If you quit the round, you turn your remaining cards face down and skip any subsequent turns. The round ends when the llama row is empty, when someone discards their final card, or when all players have quit. (When all but one player have quit, the final player can keep taking turns as long as they like, but if none of the dice match cards in their row, then they automatically bust and take all cards in the llama row.) You then look at the cards remaining in front of you and collect points: 10 points if you have one or more llama cards, and points equal to the card value, with each number card counting only once. If you discarded all of your cards, you can discard a previously collected point token. (Tokens are worth either 1 or 10 points, and you can always swap ten 1s for a 10 token.)

You play multiple rounds until one player has collected 40 or more points, at which time the player with the fewest points wins.
With war fever in the north at its zenith, the stage is set – for Lincoln’s invasion of the south!

All Hell Let Loose is a set of WW2 late war wargaming rules designed and playtested to encourage real-life tactics. Although created specifically for 6mm (or 1/285th scale) miniatures the rules can be used for larger sized miniatures like 10mm with minimal changes.

The rules allow you to play at the scale you choose - either 1 model or stand of infantry represents 1 vehicle or squad/section of infantry or each model or stand can represent a platoon.

Optional rules let you dial up the detail and zoom in on the minutia of combat or skip them to play really big games more quickly.

Simple and adaptable late war European theatre army lists with each of the four major powers for that theatre included: British, American, Soviet and German.

A two-page quick reference sheet allows you to play without needing to reference the core rules and the rules include a photocopy ready counter sheet that provides counters for hidden movement, ambush and target markers for indirect fire and aircraft attacks.


     Fast play, simple rules that encourage real-life tactics
     All the rules you need to get started in one book
     Simple army lists for late war European eastern and western front
     Flexible figure scale and basing system
     Rules for the fog of war and for hidden movement
     Suitable for solo play all the way up to multiplayer club sized games
     No record-keeping or order writing necessary
     Optional rules for weather, darkness, engineers and high ground
     Photocopy ready counter sheet
     Photocopy ready quick reference sheet


—description from the publisher

Terraternity is a sustainable thematic game. You're invited to save Terra in combating climate change in a coop or competitive mode. Play the world countries, build renewable power plants to reduce fossil-based CO2. Carbon neutralizes countries before 5 climate disasters or 10 years ends the game. A game plays around 90-120 minutes. Are you ready to save Terra? Terra is the Latin word for earth, and eternity means the infinite time that never ends. We created Terraternity to raise awareness about the efforts needed to heal our planet and preserve it for future generations. Every day we all place more CO2 on our planet without effort living our lives. In Terraternity, we created a game mechanic placing CO2 cubes on a Terra Globe. This is easy and fun, and when the game progressed, it creates challenges, tension, and hopefully awareness.

Your goal is to develop renewable power plants in various countries to make them carbon neutral. You will first need to ‘activate’ a country, which lets you build renewable power plants within it but adding its CO2 output - literally! - to the Terraternity globe. You’ll need to make sure this globe stays balanced - too many CO2 cubes, and you risk a climate disaster - while also balancing that country’s CO2 footprint. Successfully balance enough countries before time runs out or disaster strikes, and you win!

You can play Terraternity in different game modes:


    Competitive: You are on your own to turn five countries carbon neutral before any other player. Keep your hand and strategy secret while you place victory points on your player board and collect green cubes from carbon neutralized countries.
    Cooperative: You work together with all players to turn eight countries carbon neutral. Everybody plays with an open hand – sharing strategies is highly recommended as you all play against the board and win or lose together!  Progress is tracked on the CO2 scale on the Game board.
    Solo: In the solo mode you play against the board and try to achieve and master the different stages. Are you able to master the MSP Stage - they highest possible challenge - which makes you the Most Sustainable Player?

2020 Retroz is a humorous card game in which you can bluff to gain an advantage. This game revolves around 2020 headline news, events and other topics. Players get to choose description cards from their hand that would relate to a given topic. The judge player then selects the best submission according to their personality. Each round consists of four phases where players can wager, judge, calculate points and replenish the cards in their hand. The rounds continue until a player reaches one of three winning conditions.

—description from the designer

The purpose of the game is to compose a hand of 11 "footballer" cards and lay them out on the table as if they were a football team, trying to obtain the highest combination value, and win the "championship".

The 104 "footballer" cards are divided into 4 roles: goalkeepers, defenders, midfielders and strickers; and each card (except for goalkeepers) has three values: left wing, centre and right wing.

At the start every player draws 1 (from 6) "Line-up" card: this card shows the number of footballer for each role and their position on the field (left, centre, right).

A player's turn consists of the following phases: 
1- draw 2 cards from the "footballer" pile, or take the top card from the discard pile
2- swap footballers with other players (not mandatory)
3- discard 1 card (only if the player drew 2 cards in phase 1)
Whenever a player has 11 cards in his hand at the end of the turn, he must declare it and from then on, he can only draw 1 card.

When a player states that he wants to close, the other players have 1 turn to try to improve their team.

The player who has lined up the team with the highest sum of the values of the footballer, is the winner.

Batalla de Calama (The Battle of Calama) reenacts the first battle in the War of the Pacific. A larger force of Chilean troops defeated a group of Bolivian soldiers and civilians near the town of Calama on March 23, 1879.

The game is a wargame for two players, one in control of the Chilean troops and one commanding the Bolivian forces. Depending on the difficulty level, the Chilean side can outnumber the Bolivian side by nearly two to one.

Battle of Calama is a simple dice game. There are dice in various colors which determine the amount of troops that can be moved, whether a change of direction is possible, and the outcome of the battles. The troop strength serves as a modifier in battle. The goal is to occupy the entire town.

ãƒ‡ãƒ¢ãƒ³ã‚ºãƒãƒ¼ãƒ  (THE DEMONS'S NAME) is a deduction game from Japan that combines logic puzzles and identity concealment. Exorcists deduce the true name of a demon, the name being a hidden four-digit number.

One player is the demon king, and chooses its secret name from four digits in order. The other players are the exorcists, and must deduce the demon's name. If they do, it loses all its power and they win.

The demon also possesses one of the exorcists in secret at the start of the game (they don't know it) and can lie when answering this exorcist, thus sowing lies in their midst.

The exorcists start the game knowing one of the digits each. They can discuss their ideas for a few minutes, and then in turn, each exorcist makes a claim of the four digit number. The demon answers in such a way that they might deduce which numbers are correct, and in the correct place.

If the exorcists discover the true name within the time limit, they win (and lose if they fail so), but only if they also can conceal who knows which number. For if they land on the correct sequence, the demon king and its possessed aide can now discuss which exorcist had which digit. If they get this correct, the demon king escapes victorious with the assistant.

The game includes rules for playing online. The game is published in Japanese and English.
user summary

The Dragon’s Lair is a frantic, fast paced treasure collection game with survival elements. Players work to evade a wide range of fierce dragon attacks while gathering an assortment of rubies, emeralds and gold. Challenge the dragon alone or with friends as you compete to gather as much treasure as you can before your luck runs out. Do you dare enter The Dragon’s Lair?

Setup:

Separate out one blink per player to be treasure hunter (player) blinks and one blink to be the dragon.
Triple click a blink to set to treasure hunter, long press to set blink to dragon (hold off until ready to start the game), double press to set back to lair tile.
Arrange all remaining non-player (lair) blinks around the dragon in any configuration desired as long as each blink has one side open for connection.
Alt Setup - If only playing with 6-9 blinks, arrange blinks in a straight line with the dragon at the end.
Long press the designated dragon blink to set role and start the game.

Rules:

Treasures randomly spawn into the lair playspace for the players to collect.
Treasure hunter (player) blinks have three colored sides - Yellow (Gold), Red (Rubies), and Green (Emeralds).
Players must match the correctly colored side of their blink to a treasure to score points.
Each red (ruby) and green (emerald) collected gains the player 1 point, while each yellow (gold) collected gives the player 5 points.
Yellow (Gold) treasures require the play to mine (be connected to them) for 3 seconds before awarding their points.
Players collect treasure points until their luck runs out (all 3 luck lost).
One luck is lost by incorrectly connecting to a treasure or by being adversely affected by a dragon attack.
The players current luck count is displayed by the three white lights on the treasure hunter blink.
The Dragon has three attacking moves:
A. Fireball - Orange light (Fire) moves quickly throughout the lair. Any player attached to an actively affected tile looses one luck.
B. Poison - Pink light (Poison) moves slowly throughout the lair. Any player attached to an actively affected tile looses one luck.
C. Void - All light is sucked from the Lair, and players must collect tiles based on their memory. The incorrect matching penalty of one health still applies.
Dragon attacks get more frequent as the game progresses eventually resulting in the end of the game.

Win Condition / End Game:

After a player has lost all of their luck, their blink changes over to score mode.
In score mode, lights of different colors flash in quick succession followed by a several second gap.
To determine your score, count the number of Gold flashes in the group and multiply by 100, and then red by 10 and green by 1. The sum of these numbers is your score.
If playing single player, try to set and beat your high score.
If playing competitively with multiple players, the player with the highest score when their luck runs out wins.

In this one to two player game you construct a city with cards, complete with roads, bike paths and subways. Once your city is constructed you equip your driver by spending points you earned building your city, then race around delivering food.

In the solo game with a definite win lose condition. You need to deliver a certain number of orders in the number of turns defined by your city score.

In the two player game you are trying to outscore your opponent.

-description from designer

PopSavvy is a game that challenges each player's social awareness. It is played by a couple sharing a bottle of wine, by friends and family groups at a dinner table, by classrooms of kids getting to know each other, and by pub crowds demonstrating their social savvy.

Players win the game by being the best at predicting how individuals or groups of people will answer thought-provoking, fun, and/or revealing YES/NO questions. The goal is to "know the crowd" better than your opponents.

Gameplay is very simple. A player selects a PopSavvy card and chooses one question from five categories - SELF, LIFE, lOVE, HOME, or WORLD. Eg. "Does drunkenness reveal the true character of a person"? Each player votes YES or NO on a scoresheet, predicts how many players will vote YES, discovers how many actually voted YES, and earns a score based on how accurate their prediction was. After several questions, the most socially savvy person will reveal themselves.

—description from the publisher

The game is played in teams of four to six people, one game per team. Each team has a playing board representing a Kanban task board, and a collection of story cards representing work to be done. Teams compete to maximise profit by optimizing the flow of work.

During the game the teams construct charts based on data from the game including a Cumulative Flow Diagram, a Run Chart, and a Lead Time Distribution Chart. Simulated events occur throughout the game to challenge the teams and require them to make various system design, prioritisation, and resource allocation decisions.

War Patrol is a 2-player fantasy battle game. Each player creates a squad of 5 warriors from a selection of 50, then squares off against the enemy in a furious close-combat fight.

After each player deploys their warriors, the members of each squad are revealed and the battle begins. Each warrior has a unique ability, realm traits, and a racial restriction. Players alternate turns with one warrior acting at a time based upon the order determined in their deployment. A warrior can use their turn to attack the enemy squad by rolling a d10 and allocating damage (called a Standard Attack) or by using their warrior ability or realm ability as an alternate way to deliver damage or otherwise alter the flow of battle.

While many warriors have offensive abilities, many others have defensive, retaliatory, healing, summoning, or a wide variety of other abilities. The interactions and synergies of the warriors each player selects for their squads will have a major impact on the battle. The first player to reduce all enemy warriors to zero health wins the game.

—description from the designer

Europe in Turmoil II follows in the footsteps of Europe in Turmoil I. Once again, two players take sides in this political CDG set in the Interbellum era between the two World Wars, this time one representing the Moderate Left (socialists and liberals), and the other player representing the Moderate Right of the time (conservatives and nationalists).

The mechanics of the game are rather similar to those of Europe in Turmoil I, with the main changes being the replacement of the Naval Arms Race by seven concurrent Rearmament races (for each of the six scoring regions of the game plus the Soviet Union) and the removal of the stability and mobilization decks in lieu of a new extremist marker that facilitates support checks.

While players represent moderates, the cards they are using contain some of the more extreme people and factions of the period. It is possible to harness their large political prowess in order to make quick gains, but at the cost of becoming less and less moderate, which may eventually hamper your possibility to win the long game.

The map represents the political reality of Europe in the Interbellum, divided in six scoring regions (Germany, France, Italy, United Kingdom, Spain and the Little Entente of Yugoslavia, Romania and Czechoslovakia).

Play progresses over three periods: The Roaring Twenties, followed by the Great Depression and finally the Appeasement period.

Europe is in Turmoil again! Will you be the one to extinguish the forces of extremism, or will you fan the flames on your way to Domination?

—description from the publisher

There are an estimated 6 million people geocaching and now you can bring that kind of fun to your living room. For those times when you and some friends just want to go on the hunt without going out, now you can.
It’s all here! Caches, geocoins, hazards, multi-caches, puzzle caches, and even muggles.
Just like real geocaching, there are surprises along the way!
Cache Me If You Can! will never play the same way twice!

This edition adds health points, battery life, cache, and terrain difficulty.

—description from the designer

Snip Rössel-Sprung (2 players)
Each player has 9 snips in 9 different colors. The snips of the players differ in their size. The goal of the game is to reach the opponents' 9 starting spaces with the snips of the same color (like in Salta). Movement is in knight-move forward and backwards on the grey and red spaces. Double moves are possible by jumping over friendly snips. If a snip has passed the red spaces into the opponents half of the game board, it can't return to its own half.

Snip-Jagd (2-4 Players)
Each player has 2 hunters, which start on the spaces marked with a "J" and a runner starting on the spaces marked with a "L". The players have to move their runner around the game board till it reaches its starting space again. Movement is determined by 2 dice. When a runner moves through an enemy's circle, he risks being caught by the two enemy hunters, which can't leave the circle. A runner may be caught by other runners, too. A caught runner returns to his starting space to begin anew. If a runner manages to catch a hunter, the hunter is out of the game permanently. The first runner to reach his starting space, after completing the track around the game board, wins the game.

—user summary

The rules are simple- On each round, the players pick up a token from the table and place it on their own bingo boards. The first player who forms a row of five pictures wins the game. The game is full of colourful pictures that children love, and the simplicity of the rules means it really is accessible even for the youngest of players!
-description from publisher's website

The difference between this game and regular Bingo is in this one there are only 4 printed pictures on the board. You spin a spinner on your turn and the result dictates if you take a red, green, yellow, or a blue tile. The tiles have symbols and you have to place them on your board trying to make 5 in a row.

There's a special sector in the spinner which lets the player move a tile on their board, thus being able to change their mind about which 5 pictures trying to get and into which row.
-user summary

House of Cats is somehow the missing game in the wide roll & write offering: easy to learn, fun to play and allowing some cheeky moves enjoyed by gamers and sly friends. Some kind of a "perfect family game" or "filler" allowing various players, from kids to core, to share a nice moment together and to tease each others in the same time.

You said "Roll, HIDE & Write" ?

On each turn, the active player rolls 3 dice but only shows 2 to other players: all the player now have to fill their individual house of cats with these two results. Then, the active player reveals the hidden die! Whether this surprise is good or bad, all players have to place it in their house, respecting a strict condition. Yes, simple! But also very cheeky... and an intense source of interaction between players.

—description from the publisher

An unknown virus that makes infected people violent has spread and the world has changed completely. A mob rushed to St. Lily’s Girls Academy and the students fled to the old school building. There they remain hidden. The girls hold their breath and wait for rescue with anxiety and fear. At dawn, one of their friends died… they can’t leave the corpse as it is as they don’t know when help will come.  The girls are divided into groups and try to embalm the corpses with the limited materials in the school while looking for clues to the murderer who may be hiding among them… in this game, the players become leaders of each team and give instructions to the team members (hands). The last hand is the leaders themselves. Will you be able to reach the truth of the incident and survive the tragedy?
—description from the publisher (translated)

In this quick card game players play cards from hand to either complete the embalming task, to place suspicion on other players, or perform a card's special action. When all players have only 1 card remaining, the game ends. The embalming is successful if the cards played to it meet the target number (based on the number of  players). Players then check their suspicion levels. The player(s) with the highest suspicion are arrested as suspects and cannot win. The remaining players then check the victory conditions of their final hand card in the priority order of the cards. If they meet the card's victory conditions then they have won the game.

—user summary

Hertzschlag is a semi-cooperative game about the power grid, renewable energies and a looming blackout.

Players represent communities of households whose decisions impact the power frequency. Getting a solar panel on your roof increases the overall amount of electricity produced and thus increases the frequency. Getting an electric car in contrast consumes more electricity, hence lowering the frequency.

Furthermore, events like unexpected and extreme weather influences how much wind and solar energy is produced and can unbalance the frequency which players need to rebalance through their choices.

Players have secret goals that award victory points at the end of the game and try to win by having most. However, if the frequency is too unbalanced and players fail at rebalancing it, a blackout happens and all players lose immediately. Concluding, players need to cooperate at least a bit to prevent a blackout. Or should you focus on your own personal goals and hope that other players will prevent a blackout?!

—description from the publisher

What does the word Advent mean?
What is the plot called in Norway?
When did Arne Weise end up as Christmas host?

What do you know about Christmas baking, Christmas trees, Christmas calendars, Christmas in other countries, Christmas food, Jesus, Santa, Lucia and much more?

Question cards, Christmas songs and Christmas rhymes for adults and children.

The game is about collecting Merry Christmas tokens. Most tokens at the end of the game win. The correct answer gives a token unless the card indicates otherwise.

There are five types of cards; Question cards, True or False cards, Christmas rhymes, Humming cards and theme cards.

—user summary

As the guns of August were heard firing across Europe, the German Kaiserliche Marine began commerce raiding in the Pacific, targeting British shipping and colonial holdings to reduce their economic ability to fight on the continent. The Empire of Japan, eager to emerge as a global power and seeing an opportunity to expand at the expense of Germany's Asian and Pacific colonies, entered the Great War alongside their British allies.

John Gorkowski's Empire at Sunrise: The Great War in Asia, 1914 depicts the struggle for control of Pacific sea lanes during the opening months of World War I. Its focus is largely on naval operations - on the cat-and-mouse dance of destroyers and battleships. The game presents its action at three different telescoping scales using nested playing surfaces, representing the area around Tsingtao at six miles per hex, the fight over the Asian Pacific at 240 miles per hex, and the entire Pacific Ocean at 1440 miles per zone. From the Battle of Coronel off the coast of Chile to the Siege of Tsingtao in China, this game elegantly captures the sweep of a forgotten chapter in the history of World War I.

—description from the publisher

This historical semi-cooperative Eurogame is set in the Ottoman Empire between 1839 and 1876, at the time of the Tanzimat reforms. The Tanzimat reforms were an ambitious attempt on the part of liberally minded Ottoman sultans and politicians to modernize the aging empire and thereby keep it from disintegrating.

Players in the game represent Ottoman court factions who enlist Statesmen to use their bonuses, enact Reforms and reduce the number of Troubles in the empire. They must keep an eye on three common resources: Finances, Army and Standing. Event cards are drawn at the start of each turn that add new Troubles to the map, possibly causing Revolts.

The game consists of two Ages. At the end of each Age, a Crisis happens. (The Crisis may happen earlier if the number of Troubles and Revolts reach a critical number.) Only one player can win, but all players can lose if they let the empire crumble.

—description from the designer
The game is fully PnP!

COMPONENT LIST
 1 rulebook
 1 game board
 40 Statesmen cards
 30 Event cards
 30 Reform cards
 24 Sultan’s Decree cards
 16 Legacy cards
 9x4 buildings (Schools, Factories, Juries)
 24 markers (partitions, Finances, Army, Standing, income, Loans, Revolts, game effects)
 40 cubes (Troubles) - not included in the game!
 5x4 cylinders (Influence, player order, VP, offices, Reform stage) - not included in the game!

ONETOP FOOTBALL is a football card game that anyone can easily enjoy with real football rules.

How to play
â‘  They are divided into home team and away team.
â‘¡ Out of 10 tactical cards, choose 5 cards to use as your tactics, mix them well with 23 player cards, and place them as shown in the picture. (Set aside tactical cards that are not used.)
â‘¢ Each player draws 5 cards from the top of the deck and holds them invisible to the other party.

Game progress
â‘  Each player turns one player card over and places them in the midfield area.
â‘¡ In the midfield area, the number of passes of player cards is compared.
â‘¢ The winning player compares the player cards in the opponent's penalty area when comparing the next player cards.
â‘£ In the penalty area, place 1 player card face down invisibly.
â‘¤ Compare the attack number of the attacking player card with the defending number of the defending player.
â‘¥ If you win by comparing player cards in the opponent's penalty area, you will score 1 point.
â‘¦ If you lose in the penalty area, return to the midfield area and compare the player cards.
â‘§ If the number of player cards to be compared is the same, compare again with other player cards on the spot.
â‘¨ The used cards are stacked in the used card deck, and the number of cards used in the new card deck is taken from the top, and the play continues while maintaining 5 cards.
â‘© Place the scored player card in front of you to make it easier to calculate the score after the game.
â‘ª Only one tactical card can be used.
(Tactical cards that are used with player cards are turned over so that the opponent cannot see them and placed next to the compared player cards.)
â‘« If one of the players has no more player cards to compare, the match ends. The player with the highest total score is the winner.
â‘¬ If the score is the same, each player selects 5 player cards randomly and compares the attack numbers one by one. The player with the highest number of cards won is the final winner.

A category card and a bonus letter are revealed each round. Players have 90 seconds to write out seven entries that fulfill the category. Only unique answers will score and entries that begin with the bonus letter earn extra points. Play continues until 4 rounds are played. Each player adds up their scores for all four rounds and the player with the most points wins the game.

The Battle of Liege was the opening engagement of the First World War and the first step of the German Schlieffen Plan. Liege, a city protected by a ring of twelve forts, blocked the passage of the German First and Second Armies. It contained the railway bridges crossing the Meuse river that would be needed by the advancing armies. Winning a quick victory over the Belgians was critical to the success of the German plan so a surprise attack of six brigades was launched ahead of the heavy artillery that ultimately destroyed the forts.

Liege 1914 is a regimental-level simulation of this opening battle of the Great War. Players assume the roles of the commanders of the German and Belgian troops as they desperately fight for this valuable position in the line.

The 17 x 22" map shows the western portion of Belgium from the German border to Liege. The 240 1/2" counters (die-cut and back-printed) show German and Belgian forces involved in the battle.

Liege 1914 is now the second installment in the Great War Battles series. Based on the Ypres 1914 game system (the first in the series), the Great War Battles is a series of games devoted to simulating battles of the First World War. Battles are covered at the brigade/regiment level using a common set of rules. Games in the series will cover a variety of situations ranging from trench warfare to open fighting.

You will make an exciting and informative stroll, by rolling dice to move, through Deventer where you ultimately have to collect three eagles. By answering questions, collecting properties and some luck you can earn enough money to buy the three eagles. Which player will win the game after several strolls through Deventer and deliver the three eagles at the missionary of the Lebuïnus Church?

Puerta Grande is a trivia game about the world of bullfighting where two, three or four players can play.

Questions cover the following categories:

     Bullfighting Dictionary
     Bullfighters and proxies
     Bullfighting concepts
     Livestock and Ranchers
     History of Bullfighting
     Bullring and Businessmen


A game for bullfighting fans of any age.

Ravenfeast includes a short, simple set of skirmish rules that play in 1-2 hours. But this free book is also a toolkit for new players, providing optional rules, army building guides, modeling tutorials, starter scenarios, and all of the extra resources you need to get started! We'll guide you step-by-step and welcome you into this fantastic hobby!

—description from the publisher

The object of the game is for the player to obtain a numerical advantage over the opponent while preventing the opponent from scoring goals. When this happens, the player is entitled to a card which authorizes him to move one of his forwards in a given direction and specific number of spaces. A forward may only score a goal from a certain specific spaces. Each period ends when the ten "penalty" cards have been used.

The forwards move according to a tricolor dice which plays a double role based on both numerical and value and its color. Thus, the die allows a man to advance the number of spaces corresponding tot he number thrown or, depending on its color, to send a man into the game (WHITE), win a face-off (RED) or scorer a goal (BLUE). The defensemen move one space at a time, in the dircestion determined by the players.

Learn about conservation and the reintroduction of endangered species back into their natural habitats in this fun and simple to play board game for 2-4 players.

The aim is simple, to release all of your monkeys back into the wild first. To achieve this, you will need to help them find food, work together, and out-compete their rivals.

Use dice to determine what options you have to place your fruit, and your monkey's movement, then position your monkeys to make sure you can pick it up first. As your monkeys are released you have fewer options making it harder to stay on ahead of your rivals.

—description from the designer

Race Royale is a fast-paced racing, party game where teams of two compete to out-race, out-wit or blast their opponents off the track! Last car on the track is the winner!

Inspired by retro top-down racing video games, this board game adaptation lets teams of two take the wheel of a fast and furious, bustling bluffing bonanza. Because the theme of the race is "top-down" the drivers can't really see where they're going and must trust in the collective movement of the pack. Just follow the leader, but does the leader know they way or is he/she just trying to trick you into driving off the road?

Out-smart your opponents, or collect power-ups, weapons to use against them. It pays to be in the lead, but as soon as you stop trusting in whoever is in front of you, you must slow down to have time to react, and before you know it, you'll fall behind!

This bluff filled party game plays well with an even number of players, from 4 to 10. You can help your team mate by passing them information when they need it the most, or prevent them from crashing at a crucial moment by clever card play. As the race goes by, the road becomes more predictable and players may be tempted to take their chances in order to gain the much desired lead. Since the track is randomly generated, the finish line could come suddenly. In order for you (and your team mate) to win, you must be the first to cross the finish line, or have the last car on the track!

—description from the designer

Every year, hundreds of thousands of high school students apply for college, competing for spaces in colleges and universities all over the world. Applying for college is a process and can be overwhelming. This exciting card game introduces players to the various components of the admissions application process. The goal is to simulate the process in a general way by providing insight on the various parts of a college application file.

After all players receive two schools to "apply" to, players take turns, drawing cards, and adding various requirements cards to their school's portfolios.  There are also action cards you can play on other player's applications to "lose" specific documents or otherwise cause them extra work in their application.

The winner is the first person to complete successful applications to two schools.

This game is endorsed by the Michigan College Access Network (MCAN).

TOZAN is a solitaire game from Japan for a mountain climber. The game is very quick to play, only five minutes, and the player must ascend and descend the 8000m mountain safely. But the mountain is capricious, and the weather changes rapidly. So the climber must be prepared, plan ahead, maintain their strength, and watch for a lucky break.

The deck is 16 cards only but has variety, so the player will be able to play the game over again and again.

Some of the cards are used to plot the climber's ascent, and health. The other cards determine the weather (Kaze (Wind), Hare (Sun), and climbing conditions (Iwa (Rocky)).
user summary

While the battle for the five kingdoms rages above the ground, there is also unrest and conflict happening below the surface. In Kingdoms of the Deep, you control six underwater factions and vie to control the most underwater territories, while gaining the most influence to call yourself ruler of the Underwater Realms.

Kingdoms of the Deep is an area control and simultaneous action selection game for 1-6 players that plays in about an hour. Balance deploying your aquatic forces across the capitals of Atlantis with fulfilling specific goals while also trying to be the only player to choose a specific action each round.

Each round, players choose their actions simultaneously, then reveal. Players then take their turns in turn order and get a bonus if they are the one that round to choose that specific action.

Players gain reputation (points) by fulfilling round goals that and having the majorities in the capital tiles during the scoring rounds.

When at least one player has played the Reset action in a round, the game tracker advances. Once the game tracker advances 9 times, the game is over and the final scoring happens!

-description from publisher

Three blind Dice is a game that includes rolling 4 total dice: 1 standard pair of 6-sided dice, and 1 pair of Sicherman dice. One dice is revealed and three are hidden. Using your logic and reasoning, deduce what the three hidden dice are by asking the right questions. Each dice guessed is points in your favor. Be the player to earn the most points and you win! Three Blind Dice is a free pdf rulesheet game that implements Sicherman Dice.

Winter, 1904: Christmas settles on the shores of Lake Michigan like snow on a Fraser fir, and with it arrives the glorious Christmas Tree Ship.

Every year, the Christmas Tree Ship sailed North from Chicago to purchase trees from farmers in Michigan and Wisconsin, then returned to sell them in the big city.

In Christmas Trees for Sail, players become holiday mirth merchants, sailing to and fro buying trees, selling them for profit, then using those profits to bring Christmas Cheer to Chicago’s needy children.

Press your luck as you brave the wind and waves, sailing North to find cheaper trees while hoping to avoid the nasty weather. Good luck... and Merry Christmas!

—description from the publisher

Parma Calcio Manager is a game in which players, in the role of coaches, face off in a series of football matches.

It is the official board game of the Parma Calcio 1913 team

Create your team during the Transfer Market then challenge your opponents: will you play defensively or will you risk everything to find the Goal? 
Climb the leaderboard by beating your opponents and managing the unexpected. 
Will you be able to win the Championship?

Cronocartes: Història de Catalunya ("Cronocards: History of Catalonia") is a card game with Catalan history theme. Each card has an image and a text that represents a key point or achievement in the Catalan history, art, gastronomy or culture.
The front and back of each card are identical except for the fact that the back of the card include also the year in which the event happened.

Each player is given 7 cards face up so that the year is not visible to them.
One card is then placed face down (so that the year is visible) on the table. 
Each player, in his/her turn, will place one of his/her cards face up before, after or  between the cards already in the table and then turn it faced down so that the year is visible. If the card has been correctly placed chronologically, the card remains on the table, otherwise, the card is discarded and the player takes  another card. The first player to finish the cards wins.

For an additional degree of difficulty, instead of discarded an incorrectly placed cards, leave it on the table face down (with the year visible) in its correct position.

This is a standalone game, but is fully compatible with similar games such as Timeline series and can be combined with them.

[Catalan translation]

Cronocartes: Història de Catalunya és un joc de cartes de temàtica històrica.
Cada carta té una imatge i un text que representa un esdeveniment o fita a la història, art, gastronomia o cultura catalanes. L'anvers i el revers de cada carta són idèntics excepte pel fet que a l'anvers figura l'any en què va ocórrer l'esdeveniment que fa referència la carta.

Es reparteixen 7 cartes a cada jugador sense que se'n vegi l'any. Després es posa una carta a la taula mostrant el revers (cara amb l'any de l'esdeveniment).
Cada jugador, al seu torn, posa una de les seves cartes abans, després o entre dues de les cartes que hi ha a la taula sense que se'n vegi l'any. Seguidament gira la carta per mostrar l'any. Si la carta s'ha col·locat correctament
(cronològicament), la carta roman a la taula. Si no es descarta la carta i el jugador agafa una altra carta nova. El primer jugador a acabar les seves cartes guanya.

Si voleu fer el joc una mica més difícil, en comptes de descartar la carta mal col·locada, deixeu-la al seu lloc cronològicament correcte.

Cronocartes és un joc complet, però completament compatible amb jocs similars com els jocs de la sèrie Timeline, pel que es pot combinar amb ells.

It was New Year’s Eve at the luxurious restaurant, The Osgood, which sits majestically atop a mountain ridge above a posh ski resort town in the Rocky Mountains. It had been snowing heavily since the morning, and the three-star chef George Osgood had closed his renowned establishment, as he did every year, in order to celebrate with his family and employees in an intimate setting.

At 63, George wanted to retire in the new year. That’s why he announced that he would be revealing his successor this evening. Everyone was awaiting his decision with bated breath.

The two chefs, Marcus and Henry, both vying to be George’s successor, served an impressive four-course menu. Everyone ate and drank copious amounts. The evening promised to be an unforgettable one.

To everyone’s surprise, George did not announce his successor during dinner, but by midnight, when the New Year was due to be welcomed with a glass of champagne on the terrace, the evening has taken an unfortunate turn. As the fireworks display over Aspen Mountain started flaring up on the horizon, the renowned chef was found dead on the terrace. Judging by the position of his body, somebody had thrown him head first over the balcony.

The police were informed immediately. Because of the heavy snow, they will not reach the on-mountain restaurant for another few hours. Until the authorities arrive, you are all on your own in solving the mystery. What happened this evening? How could this New Year’s celebration have ended so tragically?

What is a murder mystery game?

You and your guests slip into the roles of the main suspects of an exciting murder case. The objective of the game is to convict the perpetrator – one of the people sitting with you at the table. This can only be achieved if the players discuss the course of events amongst themselves and compare their experiences of what happened. But be careful: Each character (including you!) has their own dark secrets which they’d be better off keeping to themselves.

You all gather in the wake of the crime and attempt to piece together your memories, with the aim of identifying the perpetrator. In each round, you recall more and more about the circumstances of the crime, as each round deals with a different period of time from the evening the crime was committed. At the end, everyone votes on who should be handed over to the police as the suspect.

Culinario Mortale is a highly interactive game. There are only a few rules, and no pre-prepared dialogue. The focus is on working through the puzzles and discussing the events together.

Alongside a well-structured game manual, each game contains game booklets for between five and eight characters (the number of players for each game can be found on the packaging and here on our website). In the game booklets, each guest will find their personal clues and a description of their role. Each game booklet also includes a brief overview of how the game works. As such, all players can jump right in. The support code included with your Culinario Mortale game will allow you to download the role descriptions in advance from our website in PDF format, and easily send them to your guests via email.

GAME CONTENT:
1 Game Manual, 7 Game Booklets, 1 Incident Booklet (includes of prologue, incidents, solution), 7 name badges, 1 support code

— description from the publisher.
